snp3.7:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Northern Āpaṇas named Āpaṇa.
snp3.7:1.4: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
snp3.7:1.6: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
snp3.7:1.7: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
snp3.7:1.8: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
snp3.7:1.9: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
snp3.7:2.1: So Keṇiya approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
snp3.7:2.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
snp3.7:2.3: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
snp3.7:2.4: Then he said to the Buddha,
snp3.7:2.5: “Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
snp3.7:2.6: When he said this, the Buddha said to him,
snp3.7:2.7: “The Saṅgha is large, Keṇiya; there are 1,250 mendicants. And you are devoted to the brahmins.”
snp3.7:3.1: For a second time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
snp3.7:3.2: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and I am devoted to the brahmins.
snp3.7:4.1: and a third time Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
